amblyopone.description: Amblyopone ants are primitive, cryptic predators often found in forest leaf litter.
amblyopone.habitat: Forests, under logs, soil, and leaf litter
amblyopone.distribution: Worldwide, especially in temperate and tropical forests
facts: Sometimes called Dracula ants for feeding on larval hemolymph

anochetus.description: Anochetus are trap-jaw ants known for rapid mandible strikes.
anochetus.habitat: Soil, under stones, and decaying wood
facts: Mandibles can snap shut in microseconds
Use jaws to escape predators by bouncing

aphaenogaster.description: Aphaenogaster ants are active foragers often involved in seed dispersal.
aphaenogaster.distribution: Widely distributed across North America and Europe
facts: Known for mutualism with myrmecochorous plants
Feed on both insects and sugary substances

azteca.description: Azteca ants are arboreal and known for forming symbiosis with tropical trees.
azteca.distribution: Neotropics, especially Central and South America
facts: Live inside hollow stems of Cecropia trees
Produce loud warning noises when disturbed

bothroponera.description: Bothroponera ants are large ground-dwelling predators.

brachyponera.description: Brachyponera ants are small but aggressive ground foragers.
brachyponera.habitat: Urban areas, leaf litter, and under rocks
brachyponera.distribution: Asia-Pacific, now invasive in many regions

camponotus.description: Camponotus ants are large and often nest in wood.
facts: Do not eat wood, only nest in it

cardiocondyla.description: Cardiocondyla ants are small and known for their wingless male castes.

carebara.description: Carebara ants range from tiny to massive in the same colony.
carebara.habitat: Soil and deep forest leaf litter
carebara.distribution: Tropics of Africa, Asia, and the Americas
facts: Include some of the smallest ant species

cataulacus.description: Cataulacus ants are arboreal and often nest in twigs and branches.
cataulacus.habitat: Tree canopies and woody plant cavities
facts: Can feign death by clinging tightly to surfaces
Some species are specialized twig nesters

colobopsis.description: Colobopsis ants are known for majors with plug-like heads used to block nest entrances.
colobopsis.habitat: Tree cavities and pre-existing plant tunnels
facts: Specialized soldier ants seal nest entrances with their heads

crematogaster.description: Crematogaster ants are acrobat ants that raise their gaster when threatened.
crematogaster.distribution: Worldwide, especially in tropical and subtropical regions
facts: Gaster held over thorax in a unique posture

diacamma.description: Diacamma ants lack queens; reproduction is performed by dominant workers.

dorylus.description: Dorylus ants, or driver ants, form massive swarms that consume anything in their path.

eciton.description: Eciton ants are classic New World army ants known for their raids and nomadic behavior.
facts: Create living bivouac nests with their bodies
Major predator of insects and spiders

gnamptogenys.description: Gnamptogenys ants are predatory and often feed on isopods and termites.
facts: Some species introduced to new regions

hypoponera.description: Hypoponera ants are small, cryptic, and often found in soil or under stones.
hypoponera.habitat: Soil, leaf litter, and rotting logs

iridomyrmex.description: Iridomyrmex ants are dominant foragers in Australian ecosystems.

kalathomyrmex.description: Kalathomyrmex is a rare genus with poorly understood ecology.

labidus.description: Labidus ants are New World army ants with underground raids.

lepisiota.description: Lepisiota ants are fast-moving and opportunistic, often forming large supercolonies.
facts: Invasive in some parts of the world
Can form supercolonies with multiple queens

leptogenys.description: Leptogenys ants are slender, fast-moving predators often with elongated mandibles.
leptogenys.habitat: Leaf litter, soil, and rotting wood
facts: Feed on isopods and other arthropods

monomorium.description: Monomorium includes the notorious pharaoh ant, a common indoor pest.
monomorium.habitat: Urban structures, soil, and leaf litter
facts: Pharaoh ant is a major indoor nuisance

mystrium.description: Mystrium ants, or Dracula ants, have unique reproductive behaviors and fast jaw movements.

nomamyrmex.description: Nomamyrmex are army ants known for raiding other ant colonies.
facts: Specialized predators of Atta leafcutter ants

nylanderia.description: Nylanderia ants are small, fast, and often form large colonies.
nylanderia.distribution: Worldwide, especially in tropics and subtropics
facts: Crazy ants are part of this genus

ochetellus.description: Ochetellus ants are small, dark ants commonly found in urban areas.

paratrechina.description: Paratrechina ants are agile and fast, often nesting in decaying wood or soil.

pheidole.description: Pheidole ants are highly diverse and known for their distinct soldier and worker castes.
pheidole.habitat: Soil, under stones, and forest floors
facts: Majors have large heads for defense and seed-cracking
Some are dominant in leaf litter communities

platythyrea.description: Platythyrea ants are rare predators that often nest in wood.

polyrhachis.description: Polyrhachis ants are diverse and often build silk-bound nests in trees.
facts: Heavily spined thorax in many species

pseudomyrmex.description: Pseudomyrmex ants are slender, large-eyed ants often involved in plant mutualisms.
facts: Sting is painful despite small size

pseudoponera.description: Pseudoponera ants are cryptic predators with simple social structures.
pseudoponera.habitat: Soil, under logs, and forest litter

solenopsis.description: Solenopsis includes fire ants, notorious for painful stings and invasiveness.
facts: Red imported fire ant is highly invasive

strumigenys.description: Strumigenys are tiny, trap-jawed ants that specialize in ambush predation.
facts: Mandibles snap shut on spring-loaded mechanism

tapinoma.description: Tapinoma ants are small and emit a pungent odor when crushed.
tapinoma.habitat: Urban areas, under rocks, and inside buildings
facts: Odorous house ant is a common species

technomyrmex.description: Technomyrmex are fast-moving ants often found indoors and in disturbed areas.
facts: Ghost ant is a known invasive

tetramorium.description: Tetramorium ants are aggressive and commonly encountered in urban areas.
facts: Pavement ant is a well-known species
Build nests under stones or sidewalks

trichomyrmex.description: Trichomyrmex are desert-adapted ants with hairy bodies.
trichomyrmex.distribution: Africa, Asia, and the Middle East
facts: Some species associated with human dwellings

vollenhovia.description: Vollenhovia ants are small, cryptic ants often found in forests.

wasmannia.description: Wasmannia ants include the invasive little fire ant, known for painful stings.
wasmannia.habitat: Soil, leaf litter, and disturbed areas

zasphinctus.description: Zasphinctus ants are specialized predators of other ants.
